Award.AwardTitle: Laboratory Astrophysics to Determine Precise Fe-Group Abundances in Metal-Poor Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Wisconsin Atomic Transition Probability (WATP) program on Fe-group ions will be continued under this award. The primary objective of this work is to produce a tightly defined Fe-group elemental abundance pattern in low metallicity (old) stars. This Fe-group abundance pattern will provide a powerful constraint on models of supernovae and will improve understanding of the Galactic chemical evolution.

The Broader Impact of the WATP program of quantitative spectroscopy will extend to fields such as lighting research and fusion plasma physics. The program will continue to pay special attention to recruiting and retaining students from underrepresented groups in astronomy, astrophysics, and physics. Outreach activities will include presentations to elementary school students.

POR.DRECONTENT: The atoms of the earth and everything on it, including people, are primarily “star dust” i.e. the ashes from stellar burning of lighter elements.    There is great Intellectual Merit in ongoing astrophysical research to understand more about the creation of the elements in stellar (nuclear fusion) burning and occasional large stellar explosions (e.g. supernovae and neutron star mergers).  Spectacular images recorded by large ground based and space telescopes have great appeal, but spectroscopy reveals much more of the detailed physics and chemistry of the Universe.  Spectroscopy is the study of the relative amounts of light of different colors or wavelengths as it interacts with or is emitted by matter.  Most of what humans now know, or may ever learn, about the details of the remote Universe is from spectroscopy.   The Univ. of Wisconsin (UW) NSF project in laboratory astrophysics is focused on developing and applying advanced techniques and technologies to accurately determine the interaction strength of various wavelengths of light with various atoms and ions.   Tunable lasers, atom and ion beams, synchrotron radiation, and some of the most powerful spectrometers in the world are used in this research.  Recent results under this NSF grant include new lab measurements on manganese, iron, and titanium (elements made via nuclear fusion in very massive stars) and rare earth elements (elements made via neutron capture in spectacular explosive events).  Spectroscopy has many applications outside of astronomy in chemistry, plasma science, and other fields.  The UW NSF laboratory astrophysics effort has a Broader Impact in making atomic spectroscopy more quantitative for all fields.
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 Normal 0 MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 The atoms of the earth and everything on it, including people, are primarily "star dust" i.e. the ashes from stellar burning of lighter elements. There is great Intellectual Merit in ongoing astrophysical research to understand more about the creation of the elements in stellar (nuclear fusion) burning and occasional large stellar explosions (e.g. supernovae and neutron star mergers). Spectacular images recorded by large ground based and space telescopes have great appeal, but spectroscopy reveals much more of the detailed physics and chemistry of the Universe. Spectroscopy is the study of the relative amounts of light of different colors or wavelengths as it interacts with or is emitted by matter. Most of what humans now know, or may ever learn, about the details of the remote Universe is from spectroscopy. The Univ. of Wisconsin (UW) NSF project in laboratory astrophysics is focused on developing and applying advanced techniques and technologies to accurately determine the interaction strength of various wavelengths of light with various atoms and ions. Tunable lasers, atom and ion beams, synchrotron radiation, and some of the most powerful spectrometers in the world are used in this research. Recent results under this NSF grant include new lab measurements on manganese, iron, and titanium (elements made via nuclear fusion in very massive stars) and rare earth elements (elements made via neutron capture in spectacular explosive events). Spectroscopy has many applications outside of astronomy in chemistry, plasma science, and other fields.
